Headline.Para: A*Star takes new targeted approach to R&D

LeadPara.Para: THE Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) is changing how it manages its research activities, in the face of shifting needs and increasing competition.

TailParas.Para: This transformation covers aspects such as funding allocation and talent development, with different types of research and development activities to be managed and evaluated differently.

At a press conference yesterday, A*Star chairman Lim Chuan Poh gave the hypothetical example of two projects - a "knowledge creation" or upstream scientific research project, and an industry-oriented one - currently assessed with similar metrics.
Under the new system, the upstream research would be evaluated mainly by measures such as publication, while the industry-oriented project would be evaluated in terms of industry collaboration.
"This will give clarity to the research group," he said. "They will do what they are best at, and they stay focused at what they're best at."

In addition, upstream research and multidisciplinary programmes will be funded entirely through competitive, merit-based funding. Previously, this funding approach applied to some but not all such activities.

A*Star managing director Raj Thampuran called this a "fit-for-purpose" approach. It is in line with the national Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2020 Plan, under which competitive funding is to form 40 per cent of public research funding, up from 20 per cent previously.
The changes apply from April 1, the start of A*Star's financial year, and do not affect existing projects.

The organisational structures of A*Star's 18 existing research units will not change. But different units or activities will now fall under one of five "constructs": technology centres, research institutes, knowledge creation activities, programmes and national platforms.
Some research units, such as the Institute of Microelectronics, will be considered "research institutes".
Funded mainly through core funds, these are industry-focused and will be assessed by measures such as engagement with industry and technology transfer.
Others, such as the Institute of High Performance Computing and the Singapore Bioimaging Consortium, are "technology centres".

They focus on developing capabilities - for example, computer modelling - needed by collaborators and other users. They are also funded mainly through core funds, but to a lesser extent than research institutes.
Both "research institutes" and "technology centres" may host "knowledge creation activities" and "programmes", another two constructs.
Knowledge creation activities aim to attract and host top research talent to advance scientific progress.
Programmes are multidisciplinary, term-limited groups of researchers tackling specific issues. An example is the BioTransformation Innovation Programme.

Finally, "national platforms" are facilities serving specific national needs, hosted and managed by A*Star but funded nationally or by multiple public bodies. These include the National Super Computing Centre.
